chunks.chunk_text: So these are your edible comforters.A comforter is something that makes you feel relaxed and feel good.Put another way, it is your comfort food, which is what we're talking about in this programme.Yes, like biscuits, comfort food is snacks and meals we like to stuff our faces with, even if it's not always good for us.We'll be discussing what actually makes us eat the stuff.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Why cant we resist comfort food_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Well, based on my biscuit eating skills, I'd say 15.It depends if he had to swallow them as well.I'm not sure about that but I'll reveal the answer later on.Now, biscuits, ice cream, crisps and pizzas are all good examples of comfort food.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Why cant we resist comfort food_.json

chunks.chunk_text: It's easy to snack on and they don't require many culinary skills.Culinary means related to cooking.Well, that makes sense, but there must be something else that is urging us to seek out this easy food.According to psychologist Shira Gabriel, it's about memories and emotional experiences.She spoke on the Food Chain podcast on BBC World Service and said her comfort food was macaroni and cheese, something that brings back memories.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Why cant we resist comfort food_.json

chunks.chunk_text: At some point in my life, those were foods that were made for me or shared with me by people who cared about me and loved me and took care of me.So because those are the foods that I had in my youth, I've associated them with sort of those feelings of being taken care of.And those associations are strong.The associations we have with food are very strong.And so by eating those foods, I'm able to activate those associations and give myself a rush
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Why cant we resist comfort food_.json

chunks.chunk_text: of positive feelings and a sense of acceptance.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Why cant we resist comfort food_.json
RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Why cant we resist comfort food_.json

chunks.chunk_text: that make up that food to do so.It's a good point and something food writer Jenny Linford talked about.Here's her theory on why that is.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Why cant we resist comfort food_.json

chunks.chunk_text: So according to Jenny's Italian friends, all food brings comfort and pleasure.Talking about specific comforting food is irrelevant.It's not important or has no connection with the discussion.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Why cant we resist comfort food_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Well, maybe we should take comfort from or feel less bad about the fact that eating any kind of food can bring us joy, warmth, happiness and comfort.So if you don't mind, I think I'll munch on another biscuit.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Why cant we resist comfort food_.json

chunks.chunk_text: I thought he ate fifteen.Was I right?No, Rob.He scoffed only seven in one minute.So maybe you can beat him.But before you do, let's recap on some of the vocabulary we've been discussing.Of course.We've been talking about comfort food – food that makes us feel good.And we described it as a comforter – something that makes us feel relaxed and feel good.We also mentioned culinary –
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Why cant we resist comfort food_.json

chunks.chunk_text: associated to cooking.And associated – which means made a connection in our mind with something.Something that is irrelevant is not important or has no connection with the discussion taking place.And something that is nuanced has small but important differences.Finally, when you take comfort in something, you don't feel so bad because of something else.
